paragraphs.text: Beating your partner is a crime, not an illness.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: What stops a man from beating up and raping his female partner?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to research published today, it is not sanctions imposed by the criminal justice system, such as prison or probation, but attending a course with other abusers
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: "Domestic violence perpetrator programmes (DVPPs): steps towards change", by the feminist academics Liz Kelly and Nicole Westmarland, is based on interviews with men who attend programmes that aim to re-educate them about their behaviour to improve the safety of women and children
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The research - which also draws on the experiences of partners of the violent men, a small number of children and the staff of these programmes- finds that "the vast majority of men who abuse their partners stop their physical and sexual violence if they attend a DVPP" and that such programmes"could play an important role in the quest to end domestic violence"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Some of the figures look impressive
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For example

paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Cases of the men using a weapon against their partner reduced from 29% to nil

paragraphs.text: But there are other findings that give me cause for concern
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Ninety per cent of the men interviewed had, prior to the course, made excuses about and attempted to justify their abusive behaviour
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: After the course, this tendency had barely reduced at all, with almost three-quarters of the men still making excuses
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Over the years
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when making plain my scepticism about DVPPs I have been told that the aim of such courses is to make perpetrators accountable and get them to face up to what they have done
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This finding shows that this is one of the weakest outcomes

paragraphs.text: On average, two women in England and Wales die each week as a result of domestic violence, a figure that has remained constant for decades
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: But that leaves almost half of the women still in fear

paragraphs.text: According to Nicole Westmarland, one of the report authors,"we have hardly any knowledge about how things like probation, fines, or even prison affect men's attitudes and behaviours towards women"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: This is true, but mainly because
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: so few perpetrators are held to account by the courts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We appear to have given up the battle to have domestic violence treated as a crime like any other - which used to be the feminist mantra- and have now declared the criminal justice system unfit for purpose in dealing with violence in the home
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We should not be giving up on the justice system before its potential effectiveness has been truly tested
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There are many ways its approach to domestic violence could be improved
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Pilot programmes should be rolled out nationwide, directing police to mandatorily arrest those who have committed acts of violence towards partners or ex-partners
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Crown Prosecution Service needs to take a more robust approach in getting perpetrators to court and speed up the process so the victim does not have to wait months for an outcome
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: During this process, the victims involved should be protected and supported by state-funded initiatives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Public education campaigns that aim to tug on the heartstrings of abusers, such as posters depicting women crying and sporting injuries, should be swapped for images of men in handcuffs or in a prison cell
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Young women and men need to be educated about what is at the root of domestic and sexual violence
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - that it is a cause and consequence of inequality and sexism

paragraphs.text: People who beat their partners are making a choice

paragraphs.text: We need to make sure the message that this is a serious crime, not an illness, is disseminated in schools

paragraphs.text: Let us return to the notion, once at the heart of the feminist challenge to domestic violence, that beating up your partner should carry as serious a consequence as assaulting a member of the public in the street
